comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/88051129@N00/3317019958/in/set-72157604032957382] from [http://www.flickr.com/photos/88051129@N00] EDIT This photo is dated September 23rd 1908 - the room is very similar to our picture above. Note the antlers over the left hand door in our photo, was it broken (and replaced or repaired) before or after this picture? Closer to 1908 than 1890 I would guess?

comment._content: There's a full description of the deer's heads, when, where they were acquired etc in this downloadable (but big!) free ebook blog.powerscourt.ie/download-free-book-on-the-history-of-... .

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Name:CASTLE, RICHARD Building:CO. WICKLOW, POWERSCOURT Date:1731-1740 Nature:New house incorporating existing castle for Richard Wingfield, M.P. (later Viscount Powerscourt).(Accidentally burnt out, 4 Nov 1974.) www.dia.ie/works/view/224/building/CO.+WICKLOW%2C+POWERSC...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: I am happy there are no dogs in this photo!!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I am sure this photo is in that ebook published in 1903, between pp 10 and 11.  'A Description and History of Powerscourt' by Viscount Powerscourt K.P., P.C.  (London, Mitchell & Hughes 1903).  He is the fellow who collected these poor creatures - nevertheless a fascinating read, see Chapter One on the Entrance Hall.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Wait a minute - the book photo has extra dead things hanging off the ceiling, so must be more recent than this photo above, ie this is pre-1903.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The dead things may not be permanent. I don't think you can deduce the date based on their presence or absence.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Well, the heads "with turnips" on the south end he bought in 1901, which would provide an earliest date if those are what we see.  Turnips anyone?!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I can kinda sorta see mounting the heads of animals you hunted yourself, but buying them in a shop? Bizarre.

comment._content: Now that's a "Man Cave"!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Hello all! Sorry for radio silence this end today. Just popping head around the door to show you a photo of our Gents' Toilets here at Library Towers! Yes, you heard/read that correctly - our Gents' Toilets (thought it might be fun for those of you far, far away who've never visited us yet). This photo won in a section of this year's Open House Dublin Photographic Competition...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: Apparently German deer heads with turnips was quite a thing. He apparently had a few of those before the 1901 purchases. In the August 1899 Country Life Illustrated he discusses his collection of trophies in some detail. Example: Three heads hang between the windows, all on beautifully-carved wooden shields, one of sixteen points, the others less; I bought these for the old carved wooden heads. Each stag bears in his mouth a turnip carved in wood, the root on one side of his mouth, the leaves on the other. These also date from the sixteenth century.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
